conclusion: Given a transverse harmonic wave propagating along the x-axis, with A=10cm in both figures.
Figure 1 shows the waveform at t=2s, and Figure 2 shows the vibration image of the particle at the abscissa x=2m.
Identify the direction of wave propagation from the given waveforms.
Calculate the wave speed using the amplitude and time information provided in the figures.
Figure 1 depicts a wave at time t=2 seconds with amplitude A=10 cm.
Figure 2 illustrates a wave at position x=2 meters with the same amplitude.
The wave is propagating along the x-axis.
In Figure 1, the wave is moving from left to right, indicating the direction of propagation.
The formula for wave speed is v = λ/T, where λ is the wavelength and T is the period.
From Figure 1, the wavelength is λ = 4 cm.
The period T is 2 seconds, as given.
Substitute the values into the wave speed formula: v = 4 cm / 2 s = 2 cm/s.
Convert the wave speed from cm/s to m/s: v = 2 x 10^-2 m/s.
Confirm the direction of wave propagation is along the x-axis, from left to right.
The wave is propagating along the x-axis, from left to right. The wave speed is 2 x 10^-2 m/s.
